High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our T&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights.
https://www.ft.com...-9d7c-be108f1c1dce

Italy’s Luxottica and France’s Essilor have agreed a €50bn merger deal, one of the largest ever European cross-border transactions, creating a global leader in the fast-growing eyewear industry.

The deal sees Luxottica, the world leading consumer eyewear group and owner of Ray-Ban, Oakley and Sunglasses Hut, merging with Essilor, the world leading manufacturer of lenses.

Leonardo Del Vecchio, Luxottica’s 81-year-old billionaire founder and Italy’s richest man, will become the largest single shareholder in the merged group with a stake between 31 and 38 per cent, though voting rights will be capped at 31 per cent. Under the terms of the deal Delfin, the Del Vecchio family holding company that controls Luxottica, will exchange its 62 per cent stake in the Italian company for newly issued Essilor shares.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

One eye on regulation, I suspect. Here's Olivetree

BE11:09am

This long expected merger seems to make strong strategic sense. The vertical combination will propel the merged entity to a global market leading position and bring with it the material synergy benefits one would expect from such a combination – perhaps significantly more meaningful than the EUR400m to 600m muted by the companies. With this synergy potential comes the reciprocal anti-trust headache. As EssilorLuxottica becomes the biggest competitor to its main clients, we are likely to see strong opposition across their customer base to the tie-up. That said, with the horizontal issues de minimis and history showing little substantive anti-trust objection to vertical tie-ups, the deal is likely to pass through the conditions to closing, albeit on a timetable that suggests almost a year before minority shareholders receive their consideration.

BE11:09am

And Jefferies.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Conclusion: The logic of creating a dominating, vertically integrated global eyewear giant and Luxottica's lack of succession has led to today's proposed merger. Cost synergies will likely represent the lion's share of today's target and, with assumed limited regulatory risk, investors should apply a high multiple to the incremental EBITDA (10x on €0.5bn vs a combined equity worth of €46.3bn?). More debatable is whether the deal creates incremental revenue opportunities at a time when both groups are displaying reducing sales growth attractions.

BE11:10am

And Natixis .......

BE11:10am

A deal that makes sense. The market has waited a long time for this merger to materialise because there is so much scope for synergies. In this morning’s press release, the companies talk of synergies amounting to between €400m and €500m in the medium term (about 3% of combined sales) and they are expected to gather pace over the long run. Note that Essilor is the global leader in ophthalmic lenses (42% of volumes), and that it has recently begun to move into the sunglasses segment (low-end and mid-range) and online segment, whereas Luxottica is by far the no.1 in sunglasses (one-third of the market) and frames, and has solid positions in the distribution of optical products, particularly in the USA.

Evenly-balanced governance. Under the terms of this deal, Delfin, Leonardo Del Vecchio’s holding company (62% stake in Luxottica), will transfer its entire stake in Luxottica to Essilor at a rate of 0.461 Essilor share for every 1 Luxottica share. A second stage will involve Essilor launching an exchange offer for the remaining shares. On completion of the deal, Delfin will own between 31% and 38% of Essilor (to be renamed EssilorLuxottica).

Leonardo Del Vecchio (currently executive chairman of Luxottica) will hold the position of Chairman/CEO of EssilorLuxottica, while Hubert Sagnières (currently executive chairman of Essilor) will become vice-Chairman/CEO of EssilorLuxottica with the same powers. The deal is expected to be finalised in H2 17 once the anti-trust authorities have given their go-ahead. Our view
is that there is little risk of overlap between the two groups’ products; the new group will clearly become a dominant player in the optical industry. We also need to find out what the reaction will be from Essilor clients that are also Luxottica’s rivals.

BE11:18am

* In an article for the Sunday Times, Brexit minister David Davis made clear that negotiating third-country free trade deals, difficult under continued customs union membership, would be a top priority. Davis also pointed to a transitional deal to smooth the UK’s exit, in line with recent rhetoric. Taken together, the reports represent a high-risk strategy for the UK’s initial negotiating stance and, in our view, are consistent with the market beginning to fully price a hard Brexit.
Most important is the Prime Minister’s reported willingness to forgo membership of the customs union. A decision on customs union membership is a preliminary to most other aspects of the Brexit process as, for example, negotiations on third country trade deals cannot begin without it. As has been well documented, a full exit from the customs union would be highly economically disruptive and would compromise investment in major UK export sectors such as autos. In recognition, the government appears to be seeking special privileges for certain sectors. It remains to be seen what the EU response will be, but the strategy is high risk. First, it would amount to a ‘pick-and-mix’ approach to Single Market Access that EU leaders have so far rebuffed. Second, unless a deal was made quickly, companies may trigger contingency plans at an early stage of the negotiations, leaving a later deal meaningless.

BE11:19am

Leaving the customs union would leave the UK a free hand to negotiate third-country trade deals, such as with China or the US. We are not optimistic, however, that third-country deals could replace the UK’s existing trade arrangements soon. Trade deals are highly complex and it would be highly challenging to negotiate them under the current political timetable. The benefits of seeking third-country deals are also questionable given increasing evidence of protectionism and slowing global trade.**

Today’s news also leaves questions over the future of UK financial services. Reports last week signaled that EU Commission negotiator Barnier was considering transitional arrangements for the City of London to safeguard lending and liquidity in the EU.

*** It is unclear, however, how full UK sovereignty from ECJ decisions can be made compatible with continued bank access to passporting and many aspects of the Eurozone’s financial infrastructure such as Target 2 and euro swaps clearing.
The reported hard-line stance is also likely to increase domestic political instability, with many MPs concerned that Single Market Access should be the highest priority for negotiations. It should also raise tensions with the Scottish government, with SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon having pledged her support for a second independence referendum if Scotland does not remain in the Single Market. In terms of next steps, we anticipate a decision on the Supreme Court appeal over the government’s Triggering of Article 50 to be likely on one the forthcoming two Wednesdays. One risk associated with the appeal is that the Supreme Court rules devolved authorities must be consulted as part of triggering Article 50. If so (not our base case), this would leave seemingly irreconcilable differences between Westminster and Holyrood’s political priorities. In terms of market implications we see today’s press reports as a material negative should they prove accurate and a catalyst for the market beginning to price hard Brexit.
As per our recent FX Blueprint publication, we see a deterioration in political rhetoric around Brexit as a key catalyst for further sterling weakness and see the large terms of trade shock from full exit from the Single Market consistent with GBP/USD at 1.06 or EUR/GBP close to parity respectively.

Daily Mail and General Trust (DMGT:LSE): Last: 770.50, down 22.5 (-2.84%), High: 789.00, Low: 768.50, Volume: 186.21k
BE11:28am

This is Exane negative, as part of a big media note.

BE11:30am

Saying print ads look bad (which we know) and also that newspapers probably won't be sold (which has been an idea that's fixated some people lately, for reasons I don't understand).

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Here's the upshot.

BE11:30am

In contrast to bulls, we see limited upside from M&A
New CEO Zwellenberg’s comments around operational ‘focus’ have raised hopes of value creative M&A as the group realises value in its diverse portfolio through disposals. We are sceptical – further sell-down of listed stakes (Euromoney and Zoopla) in our view will likely occur at a discount to the current share price, limiting upside (reflecting size of the assets and limited strategic buyer interest in the stakes). We believe the family ownership structure of the company and pension deficit limit the prospect of a print newspaper exit. The fragmented events space is consolidating and DMG events is a coveted asset that could realise an attractive multiple – however we see limited prospects of a premium to our cGBP400m valuation. We view RMS and DMGi as core to the group’s long term strategy but RMS(one) issues and UK Brexit-related headwinds limit the appeal of DMGi and RMS to 3rd parties.

BE11:30am

We stand c3% below FY18 EPS consensus forecasts but see risk as skewed to the downside. At RMS we forecast organic revenue growth to accelerate to 9% in FY18 as RMS(one) starts to gain traction, with limited conviction based on the company’s limited communication and conversations with insurance industry contacts. In a scenario where RMS(one) fails to deliver material revenue,
we could see group EBITA downgrades near 10% (assuming no cost savings). At DMG media, we assume print ad declines stabilise at c-9%, which may prove optimistic if Brexit pressures accelerate structural changes in the UK ad market. We are more sanguine on the risk of disappointment at DMGi Property, where we expect transaction volumes to be more resilient.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

In terms of exiting newspapers ........

BE11:30am

– Exit print newspapers? While CEO Zwellenberg argued there were ‘no sacred cows’ at the FY16 results, we do not believe the Harmsworth family, which controls 100% of the voting rights of DMGT, is willing to support an exit from its major print newspaper publications (Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday) based on the importance of the brands to the family legacy. Additionally, we estimate a sizeable share of the pension deficit sits with print legacy employees complicating any separation. Recent news flow around a Northern & Shell / Trinity Mirror combination may bring hopes of a bid for the print mail assets – we see this as unlikely for the aforementioned reasons.

BE11:30am

........ and on print ad revenue .....

BE11:34am

BE11:34am

The stock has risen 47% from the lowest point following the EU referendum. At the current valuation (c.0.7x last reported TBV) our price target implies broadly sector-average upside potential (24%); consequently we downgrade RBS to Neutral (from Buy). Since being added to the Buy List on March 15, 2016, RBS’s shares are down 7% vs. the FTSE World Europe up 19% (in GBP) and our EU banks coverage up 5%. We attribute the underperformance relative to the sector chiefly to the impact of the referendum outcome, which led us to significantly reduce our earnings forecasts due to expectations of lower loan growth and rates and higher credit costs.

BE11:41am

And perhaps that the Trump effect won't last forever. I mean, fingers crossed ....

BE11:41am

Here's Barclays.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Ashmore’s Q2 17 IMS reported -$0.7bn of net outflows, a sequential deterioration from flat for qtr-to-Sep and worse than the +$0.1bn we were looking for. AUM is down -4% qoq to $52.2bn, vs our $52.6bn forecast due to the flows miss. As we previously cautioned against in our last note on the name ('Uncertain outlook for EM once more, 9 Jan 2016'), Ashmore suffered an interruption to their four qtrs of flow improvement trend, due to impact of US elections, rising US yields and renewed strength of USD. Outflows were mainly from local currency and external debt, with the IMS detailing a small number of segregated mandate redemptions and a reduction of US mutual fund flows around the US elections. Overlay and Blended Debt delivered net inflows, whilst flows were neutral in Corporate Debt, Equities and Alternatives. Mgmt outlook attempted to reassure that these outflows were due to profit taking trades in Nov rather than a definite cooling of EM sentiment, but the “Trump effect” was short lived with prices strengthening in Dec and continuing into the New Year, and that they are confident of a “strong performance in 20176 and a return to the improving trend for most of 2016”. We remain cautious around Trump’s protectionist rhetoric and EM sentiment affecting capital outflows even despite a more constructive house view on EM fundamentals as per our EM strategists.

BE11:42am

Investment performance impacted by US elections in Q4

Investment performance in the qtr-to-Dec was impacted by the steepening of yield curves and USD strength as a result of Trump’s election in the US, as we expected. There was negative performance in local currency, blended debt, external debt and to a lesser extent in corporate debt and equities while other investment themes remained flat. However, management details that Ashmore’s performance remains strong relative to benchmarks across all fixed income and equity themes. Overall, 1yr and 3yr performance still remain good relative to benchmarks with all investment themes outperforming.

Management outlook tries to reassure this quarter’s outflows is more of a blip

Management outlook is on the more optimistic side with respect to investor sentiment and growth prospects in EM assets. They concede that the qtr-to-Dec was negatively impacted by the US elections and the resulting US dollar strength, and higher yield curves affected investor sentiment towards EM and interrupted the positive momentum seen earlier in 2016. However, they detail that this was short lived and asset prices have strengthened in Dec and into 2017. Further, they believe absolute and relative returns, GDP growth and current low allocations will support management expectations of strong performance in 2017 and the improved flow trend seen earlier in 2016 is expected to return.

Share price performance and valuation

Ashmore was the best performing asset manager in 2016 +11% in line with the FTSE AllShare and vs sector average -11% despite a -19% sell off in Q4. In 2017 so far the share has been flattish -0.3% vs FTSE AllShare +2.5%. However, valuation looks stretch as it still trading at 18x 2017E PE, the highest among its peers and vs. sector avg ~14.5x.

BE11:42am

And UBS.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

Looking at the eight different strategies Ashmore manages, only one saw AUMs increase during the quarter (the low-margin Overlay/Liquidity strategy), driven by positive fund flows. AUMs in Ashmore's alternative strategy were flat while AUMs declined in 6 of the other 7 strategies during the quarter. The sharpest declines to AUMs came in external debt and local currency (-7% & -9% QoQ, respectively).

BE11:43am

Our calculations suggest Ashmore should experience a 13% increase to its bottom-line for every 10% decline in the GBP vs. the US$. This means it benefits the most in our coverage group from the falling GBP. With the GBP falling 4.6% against the US$
during the December quarter, this should provide solid tailwinds to Ashmore's H1 2017 earnings. In fact, when measuring the QoQ change to Ashmore's AUMs on a GBP- denominated basis, its AUMs actually grew during the quarter by 0.6% (vs. a 4.4% US$-denominated decline).

BE11:43am

Our 350p price target is based on a discounted cash flow model using a 10.0% cost of equity and a terminal growth rate of 1.8%. The firm is currently trading at 15.3x our 2017e EPS estimates and 14.4x 2018e EPS estimates. Excluding the impact of the £360mn of cash on its balance sheet (as of June 2016), Ashmore's P/E is 12.6x 2017e estimates.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

All of which adds up to a neutral stance.

PM11:45am

LSEG notes the publication of an independent study by Prof. Dr. Dirk Schiereck, Chair of Corporate Finance at Technische Universität Darmstadt, in relation to the merger between Deutsche Börse and the London Stock Exchange Group. LSEG further notes consequent recent press speculation in relation to the possible future location of certain of its businesses as a result of the completion of the merger.

PM11:45am

For the avoidance of doubt, such action is not contemplated and any statements suggesting otherwise are inaccurate and misguided. As was stated in the LSEG Scheme of Arrangement Circular dated 1 June 2016, LSEG and Deutsche Börse are committed to maintaining the strengths and capabilities of their respective operations in London and Frankfurt. Further, the existing regulatory framework of all regulated entities will remain unchanged and, in particular, there is no intention to move the locations of Eurex or Clearstream from Frankfurt, LCH from London and the US, Monte Titoli from Milan or CC&G from Rome following completion.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Positive on Anglo, turning more positive on copper

BE11:51am

David Pleming's your analyst here.

BE11:51am

Long-term prices raised for copper and all coals: While we expect all bulk commodity prices to decline over the course of the next year, this decline will be less pronounced than previously forecast. The reduction in Chinese coal production will also likely have a lasting impact, a favourable impact on international pricing and a tighter than expected copper market brings the need for new production to balance the market earlier-than-expected and at a higher incentive price. Commodity price upgrades in the near-to-medium term are material for the bulks and copper with LT pricing up between 5-13%.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Significant earnings and valuation upgrades: Earnings upgrades are between 70-80% for the four companies in CY2017, but the changes are more moderate from 2018 at between 10-30%. These changes highlight the extreme price volatility and forecast risk inherent in mining equities. Some of this volatility is smoothed out using our DCF methodology for valuations, but still the increases in valuations are material with GLEN raised the most (by 40%) and RIO the least (by 24%).

What will they do with the excess cash? With demand growth much lower and many of the commodities more mature, the propensity for volumetric growth is a lot less than the past. Against this background we expect the emphasis to be on balance sheet strengthening and higher shareholder returns, initially through dividends. Any M&A will likely be modest and one senses if any large deals are done, it will more likely be for paper and it will be imperative that such a deal will be NPV accretive.

BE11:52am

.... who's South Africa based, judging by his phone number.

BE11:52am

Upgrade AAL to Buy (on earnings growth and valuation), Reiterate Buy on GLEN and RIO and Hold on BLT: GLEN still has the most upside (+42%) with BLT at the lower end (+9%). AAL and BLT also carry the most risk to the expected increase in commodity prices, with the spot PGM basket and Brent price still c40% below forecast LT prices.

BE11:55am

What A Potential Combined Entity Could Look Like. Assuming a potential combination does go through, it would create an African-focused gold miner balanced roughly between east (ACA: Tanzania) and west (EDV: Mali, Burkina Faso, Ghana and Côte d’Ivoire). Based on JefE for ACA and the mid-point of company guidance for EDV, current production (2016E) would total 1.4Moz at AISC of c$925/oz. Looking ahead to 2018, again under the same assumptions, this would see production grow to 1.7Moz at AISC of c$830/oz. At that scale, it would be one of the largest gold miners operating on the continent.

Endeavour Mining. EDV is a mid-sized, Toronto-listed gold miner with a market cap of $1.7bn. As highlighted above, EDV is targeting 2016 gold production of 575-610koz from its 5 producing mines at AISC of $870-920/oz. As of 3Q16, EDV has $14m net debt and on consensus estimates trades at 6.2x 2017E EV/EBITDA.

BE11:55am

Or Canaccord, if you prefer.

BE11:55am

What is Endeavour?
The company is a mid-sized Toronto-listed gold mining company with a market capitalisation of c.C$2.2bn (US$1.7bn) and gold mining assets in West Africa. Endeavour is owned 29% by La Mancha, the private natural resource investment vehicle of the Egyptian Sawiris family. The company has five mines: Agbaou (85%-owned) and Ity (55%) in Cote d'Ivoire, Tabakoto (80-90%) in Mali, Karma (90%) in Burkina Faso and Nzema (90%) in Ghana. Together, these mines were expected to produce 575-610,000oz of gold in 2016 at an All-in Sustaining Cost (AISC) of US$870-920/oz. The development of the Hounde project in Burkina Faso is expected to lift group production to +900,000ozpa at AISC of c.US$800/oz by 2018. Net debt at 30th September 2016 was just US$14M.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

And Acacia?
London-listed Acacia Mining has a market capitalisation of £1.7bn (US$2.1bn) and is 64% owned by Barrick Gold (ABX-TSX: C$22.16 | BUY), covered by Tony Lesiak, Canaccord Genuity Corp. (Canada). Barrick is looking to reduce debt and focus on its core assets in the Americas, and is known to have been trying to sell its Acacia stake in 2016. Acacia has three gold mines in Tanzania and is expected to have produced c.820,000oz of gold in 2016, at AISC at the bottom end of its US$950-980/oz range (this figure is inclusive of c.US$50/oz of share-based payment costs). The company also has interesting exploration prospects in Burkina Faso and Mali (with some potential synergies with Endeavour) as well as in East Africa. Acacia had net cash of US$203M at 30th September 2016.

BE11:56am

Does a deal make sense?
Endeavour has near-term growth; Acacia adds stable production and exploration upside. The combined company could be producing c.1.6-1.8Moz by 2018, at AISC of c.US$750-850/oz. A transaction would allow Barrick to exit all or a large part of its shareholding in Acacia, and allow La Mancha potentially a smaller equity position in a larger gold mining company. A merger could be an effective way for Endeavour to gain a listing in London. The assets, and management teams, would appear to complement one another. In our view, on a qualitative basis, a deal would make sense; it all comes down to relative valuation and, as both companies have said, discussions may or may not result in agreement of a transaction.
